title: What is the best drum set under $1000? - Quora

response.answer_text: Okay. So, by drum set, is that a shell pack (just the drums) or is it a fully stocked kit with hardware and cymbals? If it’s a shell pack, you’ve got more options. Let’s also cover the fact that when it comes to buying drums, you need to consider a couple of things. First, you need to know your desired configuration. How many toms do you want? Do you want one rack tom and two floor toms or do you want 3 rack toms and one floor tom? Do you want two kick drums or just one? Don’t forget about quality over quantity. Some kits like the Tama Superstar Hyperdrive are 8 piece kits, with two kick drums, three rack toms, two floor toms, and a snare. It’s around $700 but from what I’ve heard, they aren’t the greatest. Now, is this your first kit or is it an upgrade? No matter the answer, you always have the option to search for used kits. This is something I highly suggest. Check eBay, Craigslist, Reverb, Guitar Center, and a bunch of different drum shops (Memphis Drum Shop, Dale’s Drum Shop, Portsmouth Drum Center, etc.) for used kits. You can score on really great kits for cheap. This doesn’t mean that buying a used kit automatically means losing quality, it just means that it isn’t brand new. I got a Ludwig Centennial 4-piece shell pack (13″ rack, 16″ and 18″ floors, 24″ kick) in red sparkle for like $800. They are usually $1499. The person bought it, used it twice, and returned it. It was officially used. It sounds amazing. That was over two years ago. Everybody loves the feeling of opening up a box and getting a new kit. So, I’m going to go ahead and answer your question about what are good kits. So, first off, stay away from OCDP. Their Venice series sounds like a cardboard box. But, some great kits are the PDP Concept Maple and Birch kits. They are 7 piece kits, three rack toms, two floor toms, kick, and snare. PDP is a DW owned brand, and DW makes arguably the best drums in the world. At around $850, you can’t really go wrong with them. Pearl’s Export series is also apparently really good for being a low-end kit. Casey Cooper, also known as Coop3rDrumm3r, is a YouTuber known for his drum covers as well as being the drum set drummer for the Georgia State University Marching Band. He uses a Pearl Export. Now he is an instructor for Drumeo, an online drumming school. These kits are around $600. Ludwig Signet is another decent line. They are around $900. I haven’t heard much, but Ludwig has been dominating the drum set making industry since the beginning. I wouldn’t doubt that a Ludwig kit would sound bad, as I’ve played on a terrible tuned Accent (low-end) and it still sounded fine. Tama has great stuff in the Imperialstar, Superstar, and Starclassic lines. Superstar is the low-end and Starclassic is more along the lines of a mid-range. Starclassic can be anywhere from $800–1500 depending upon the sizes, configuration, finish, shell material, and purpose (study versus stage). I hoped this all helped.

Here's one I've been looking at:  Crush Drums "Chameleon Ash."  It's still technically an up-and-coming company, but the drums sound phenomenal, and a five-piece kit will set you back around $999 US.  They have some great features, usually found on more expensive custom kits from other manufacturers.  Crush has been quietly (?) building up quite an artists' roster, as well.
